div.p:
I shd should not have
let others be before me in men-
-tioning mentioning my little woman's intended
wedding, but that at the time
when I found her romance near
its last chapter, I was afflicted
sadly by recurring reports of
evil abot about her uncle in India
which indeed for me made it
impossible to enter rightly at the
feelings of the younger generation.
Moreover I was then as I am
still in a poor uncomfortable
state of health myself - but of
that no more. And I know how
heartily you will rejoice that I can
now

report favourably as this W. Scott
I had by last mail a letter from
himself dated 22d October. He
had removed on the 10th to the
home of a friend of his & relation
& namesake of mine some few
miles on the way frm from
Bangalore
to Madras. During the intervening
days he had been sensibly
gathering strength & he & his wife
& his host (whose letters also I
have seen) concurred in
thinking that he wd
would speedily
be able to continue his journey
and embark for England. He
cd could have no other chance but in
the sea voyage & home of a
permanent care after a most
severe case of abscess in the
liver. I hope & trust I shall
have him here anon & that
his constitution may have
so rallied as & to afford him
the prospect of a tranquil
Evening of life in the country.
That he shd should be well enough
for active service, at least
for several years to come, my
medical friends assure me is
in the highest degree improbable.
Since you will not come to
Londn London
I must go to Ireland
& bye & bye I am likely to be
a free batchelor bachelor

Eugh! My son is daily expecting
to join his regimt regiment at Canterbury
& Miss Charlotte will I suppose
be taken fr from me at Easter
or at latest in the Summer.
They are both now in Scotland
where had I been well engh enough
to travel I shd should have been
w with them at Chrs for line season
- but that over they will come
up without delay. They have
had a very happy Summer &
Autum there & he may
not have the like again
for years to come.

Charlotte will be a terrible
loss to my fireside - but I
must consider how soon the
railway is to annihilate
distance - & let any rate
I am not so silly as to
let my thoughts rest on anything
but the great comfort of
knowing that she is to be
provided w with a kind protector
of her own standing in place
of a worn & weary papa
I think myself entitled
to count on her many chances

as most fathers ought to
anticipate of a tranquil
& happy lot for my
child: & the residence of
her promisso is within
15 miles of my brother's
place, so that in days to
come her brother & she
are likely to be my neighbours

I know well that you
have had Sad new
affliction - but nothing
1846 Def
Mr Lockhart

can ever render you indifferent
to either the good or the evil
that befals befalls a friend - I
hope Mrs Wilson when
she must leave you
is to bring me some
comfortable tidings
